Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The impact of shifts in social network structure on cooperative behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social scientists have long been interested in how a person's social relationships impact their behavior, but they have typically only analyzed single social networks, like a friendship network. This project proposes, however, that looking at a single social network instead of the entirety of someone's social interactions limits our understanding of cooperative behavior, and may even give us the wrong answer. This project, which trains a graduate student in conducting rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, explores social network data from multiple domains. The project would enhance scientific understanding by broadly disseminating findings to organizations, officials, and scientists engaged in identifying effective models for international development. Through outreach activities that develop modules focused on the drivers of human change, the project would also integrate the research findings into the teaching of science at the K-12 and university level.

Curtis Atkisson, under the supervision of Dr. Monique Borgerhoff Mulder will investigate how an individual's cooperative behavior is impacted by all of their social interactions as well as the community they are in. The project proposes that the amount of overlap between an individual's different social networks will predict their cooperative behavior - both towards people they know and strangers. The project further proposes that the integration of social networks across a community will also account for cooperative behavior. This will help explain the often reported result that an individual's community is a primary determinant of their cooperative behavior. These results have great potential to help us understand changes in cooperative behaviors as societies change, and better foster cooperation in our own communities. The researcher will investigate these ideas in a set of communities that are expected to differ in the overlap of their social networks in an indigenous area of Guyana. Anthropological studies of cooperation and decision-making are typically situated in such small-scale societies, which because of their relatively homogeneity and historic insularity, tend to more effectively control for the variables being queried. U surveys, economic games, and detailed interviews, the scientists will bring the methodological holism of anthropology to bear on the analysis of multiple social networks, their overlap, and cooperation. One of the compelling aspects of this project is that it brings together multiple distinct areas of anthropology, serving as an example for the deep integration of the rigor of scientific inquiry and social theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research took place in Guyana amongst the Makushi people across two years. In these two years, 270 quantitative interviews were conducted. These interviews included extensive demographic questions, a section on naturalistic cooperation, information on social networks, and economic games (measures of willingness to cooperate with unknown people). Qualitative interviews were also conducted to get a sense of how cooperation has been changing in each village. The goal of gathering these data was to test the idea that individuals who interact with the same people in different areas of their life (have high overlap in social networks) are less cooperative with strangers and more cooperative with each other than people who interact with many different people in different areas of their life. A further prediction was that people in groups that have high overlap will be less cooperative with strangers than people in groups with low overlap. It was further predicted that people in groups with high overlap do not have a strict norm of cooperating with strangers, and instead can choose how to display their willingness to cooperate with strangers.

All three things are found to be true in a preliminary analysis. Figure 1 shows the group mean overlap plotted by the offer individuals made in a dictator game The lines in this figure show the different predictions mentioned above. The black line shows that as mean group overlap increases, individual offers decrease. The blue line shows that as mean individual overlap increases, individual offers decreases. And the red line shows that individuals in groups with high mean levels of overlap who themselves have high overlap have increased offers in the dictator game. This means that individuals without a strong norm of cooperating with unknown people can engage in that cooperation to their benefit.

In contrast to these economic games that measure willingness to cooperate with an unknown person, this population engages in two main forms of cooperative behavior. Each week the entire village does collective labor in the village and they call this village work. They also work together in small groups to accomplish large tasks for individual households, such as putting new leaves on a house roof, and they call this matriman. Households can call matriman and individuals can attend matriman. Given these are cooperative events with people who will, largely, be in their social networks, we would expect that increased levels of overlap lead to increased cooperation. Indeed, this is the case for village work and attending matriman, while overlap negatively predicts calling matriman. Mean group level overlap, however, positively predicts all forms of cooperation.

These results are important for understanding how cooperation may work around the world, both in developed countries and environments such as this. The social environment in many developed areas of the world is one with little overlap between networks: we pray with different people than we play with and than we work with. These results would lead us to think that this type of environment might lead to lower levels of cooperation with current partners, and higher levels of cooperation with unknown people. This can have consequences for things such as cooperation among small teams in corporations. A museum exhibit is being developed to communicate these results and additional avenues for applying this work in our own country are being explored.

These results are also important for understanding how cooperation works in places that are important to the future and health of the world. Places such as Guyana, which has the largest contiguous block of primary rainforest in the world, are important carbon stores and maintaining those carbon stores is important in ameliorating the effects of global climate change. Concrete recommendations for encouraging cooperation both within villages to prevent deforestation and with outside experts to develop policy can be derived from this work. I am currently working with a local development group (the North Rupununi District Development Board) to translate these results into recommendations that can be implemented in villages throughout the region.
